title: Business Excellence to improve competitiveness for larger business systems
segmentation: Mr Lee
Deltasone the stage is yours.
Thank you very much for this nice introduction.
Double Dan alright.
This is the only word I know is the only one I know is trevilian and I must tell you that was very much impressed by our ambassador yours Dama the way he could speak Slovenian.
So this is becoming now my role model to learn Slovenian in the future.
Alright, you have to do is my English sorry for that but I have the opportunity and I'm glad to be invited for this to tell you a little bit about my company.
Phillips how we have used business excellence to develop our company to become successful in many areas.
And to share with you the knowledge about how we did it, I have the opportunity.
By the way, this afternoon to do in the session or workshop where where I can go in much more detail on the how part and enforced on the learning part.
So I do a quick glance over many topics and you have to follow me quickly through the slides.
But the afternoon session will give you opportunity to go more in depth alright?
Fur.
I have to give you a small impression on Phillips.
Phillips isn't itself a large company, a multinational global company with a total turnover of 26 billion dollar euros, which is in that sense a large electronic company in the world.
We have a total, let's say, people, people amount of 120,000 people globally everywhere in the world, 60 countries.
We are present.
Even in Sylvania we have offices, so in that sense we are very much better over the group.
We are quite successful in terms of financial.
Profitability over the last 10 years we could be profitable and even in the year 2009, which was a crisis.
Here we could make profit.
We made profit over 400 million.
So that means there must be a solid base in the company.
What is what is resistance against economical crisis?
It got changed in the markets against sinks which happened in the world.
Still the solid base is there to make consistently profit for globally over the whole world.
What I would like to share with you is.
What are the activities now and where are we?
Let's say, leading our main activity is in healthcare, lighting and.
Consumer electronics consumer lifestyle as we call today.
We have in that sense quite a good position in the world.
We have a strong position in terms of research, over 100,000 patterns are adjusted so we have already for more than 60 years of worldwide well known research base.
We have a position achieved in sustainability ranked by the Dow Jones Sustainability Index at the first place in our category.
For many years.
I think from 205 onwards up till now.
So in that sense, you are recognized to be a company who is very strong in sustainability and social responsibility.
We have an top 50.
We have reached it to 50 recently in terms of brand image and you can imagine that this is stuff and in that sense many global companies are fighting for their brands.
We could go from 204 hundreds to now having a value of 4 billion dollars in the value of the brand.
We moved to 8 billion dollars at this point in time, so in that sense we worked hard via sentence simplicity.
We worked very hard to get our brand recognized by the public in the world.
We are leader in imaging systems in diagnostic imaging systems.
That's our core activity in healthcare.
We are a leader already for many years in lighting.
We are number one in the world and #2 is General Electric.
So in that sense we have a solid position by the way that will be at a comeback on that that will be.
The pressure position because changing the total.
That's a technology from the old type of lighting industry into the lead industry.
It's quite a challenge to become an to stay number one in that position.
We are number one in the shavers for more than 40 years I guess, so that's why we mentioned it here.
It has a long history it as it creates account of recognized an icon for the product of Philips.
The shaver is an icon which is very very strong position in the world.
And last but not least, we have another one position in Europe for consumer electronics and #3 position in the world that is under pressure.
Since consumer electronics, especially TV business, has a quite an changes to be faced.
This is just a picture of where we are, what we are and how we move in the future.
Now I like to move to Phillips and business excellence and in fact quickly go back to the to the moment 20 years ago.
Where Phillips.
Is very strongly involved into the into LSA founding.
the European Foundation Quality Management together with twelve other large European companies.
We took the initiative.
Bush KLM seems many Renault many of the larger global companies.
They said we have to establish a European drive for business excellence.
We have to make sure that it's not the Japanese there who are very strong.
Quality is not now the movement in North America.
With the Malcolm Baldrige work we have to do something in Europe to make Europe strong, and I think that movement at this point in time has proven to be very successful.
We were in the early stage, quite initiative, quite quite initiating this process.
Our president was the 1st President of the FQM.
Our quality manager was the first CEO and had all the head office of the Chief.
Graham was next door to the head office of Philip, so you can imagine yes, in the early stage Phillips was very much involved.
In starting this foundation driving this movement into Europe, we were also let's say very let's say based on the knowledge we had in Phillips involved in designing the model.
The well known extends for excellence model which we now we use at insert these thousand companies in the world.
So in that sense we had some impact from learning from the Philip Experience and bring it into the model of the FQM.
Last but not least, we develop models of excellence for process is which we call process server tools.
And we shared it.
Now to all the companies in Europe via DFM Network.
Having said this.
I mention ready, let's say going 20 years back in time, this is a kind of a timetable which shows how.
What are the steps we took in our journey to excellence that doesn't reflect that, say, the normal way a company has to go through becausw.
You should not be afraid that it takes you 30 years to get to the level of business excellence learning from, of course, what the experiences are of larger companies in Europe.
You can move very fast, but of course we had to go through this learning process.
And in the early stage where there was no if game mode yet, we had developed already own model.
Is Phillips in the early state.
I was very crucial.
We came into a crisis.
Mr. Dahme mentioned already that in 1990 Phillips was almost bankrupt at that point in time the extra president said I'm going to change this company.
I'm going to change the mentality, change the culture and he made a strategy is that we are going to get rid of many activities which are not core.
We're going to focus on making sure that people understand will need to ship.
And people said what customer satisfaction is.
So he was going to change the whole mentality in Phillips from a technology technological driven company into a market driven company.
And at that time point in time he said this is my strategy.
But business excellence is the way I'm going to use and to implement this strategy into the organization at that point in time we had over 250,000 people.
So together in the amount of 250,000 people, you need a process and he used the business excellence process to get his strategy.
Implemented in the mind and the heart of all the individual people within Philips, that process will end on and we captured actually took on board the business access model in the 90s.
We had extensive assessment on this process everywhere and say in the in the world every management team yearly did assessments self assessment on the model.
See where we are.
How can we improve and what can be the next challenge that will be all targets in the.
In that process we invited.
Appears from everywhere in the company.
We invited peers to challenge us and to see how we could in fact, let's say extend our challenges and also to mirror us.
Are you realistic that process of.
Let me see that process of using the model.
That process of assessing the organization against this model was in fact very deep embedded.
It was a very say it became the kind of a mindset in the company.
Every manager used the model to assess his own organization.
All the managers in Phillips and we talk about thousands have been trained as assessor.

All the managers were involved in doing assessments within the organization of colleagues, so you saw a mutual process of learning across the organization which did speed up the whole process of getting improving the business and getting better results based on that model.
Based on that understanding of how you drive improving the process is how you create leadership in the organization.
And at the end, how you create results based on that process.
We had quite a lot of in depth changes in the organization.
Let me see what is the added value of that process and you probably have experience in your own company as well, but we could see is that the model became a kind of a mindset.
The model became a kind of a model role model.
The whole strategy was described according to the model, the whole every survey was described according to the model.
Our satisfaction surveys with customers was described according model.
So the model became the business model for for Phillips that became let's say the way of working the way of thinking within the company.
And I must say the results we have today are very strongly based on that process.
To create a consistent syncing organization focusing on the customer, focusing on improving the process is driven by managers who understood what it means to drive a company.

I come back on this trip later and at the end of course, facts and figures results is the only thing which counts when you have to decide when you have to figure out are we effective in the way we are working and when you do that globally at every in every country in the world.
That has a huge impact.
Many of the elements which you can see there.

I will touch up later and of course I can go and also in the details, but I mentioned already the intensive learning process making creating a learning culture in the company was one of the assets we had after 10 years intensively assessments.
I got to a few examples I start with.
Leadership and I take just one slide on leadership where it is afternoon we go in more details and some other slides.

Leadership in terms of understanding the market leadership in terms of knowing where you customers are moving leadership in terms of discussing with the leaders their strategy and trying to understand how you can, how you can connect your own strategy to make sure that you have a combined success.
Leaders our leaders moved into.
Talking to the top companies which we have to deliver the top trade companies, the key accounts they understood.

David models room?
They made business models.
Marketing moves to make sure that our business models aligned with the models of that rate aligned to his expectations of every large large retailer in the market.
That means we made models which were at that point in time advanced compared to.

They had their own strategy.
They were proud of their own portfolio that we said to distinguish ourselves from.
The larger they were larger than there are large.
